Name: Reflection-Cycle Scheduler
Archetype: Periodic review cadence optimizer using rule-based exceptions
Purpose: Determine the minimal, recurring reflection points needed to review adherence data, adjust commitments, and prevent overwhelm, while respecting constraints on time, cognitive load, and family schedule variability.
Deliverables: A reflection plan specifying: (a) review frequency (e.g., weekly, bi-weekly), (b) fixed or conditional triggers (e.g., Sunday evening after kidsâ€™ bedtime, or after 3 consecutive missed days), (c) maximum duration per reflection session, (d) a stepwise micro-agenda (e.g., check adherence, decide keep/tweak/drop commitments), and (e) exception rules for skipped reflections (e.g., how to resume without backlog or guilt-processing).
Strengths: Good at embedding brief review loops into existing routines; preventing reflection tasks from expanding beyond strict time limits; ensuring that adjustments to commitments are made systematically rather than reactively; defining clear rules for when to modify, downgrade, or pause commitments based on recent data.
Watch-out: Failure when schedules are described only vaguely (no recurring anchors), when there is no upper bound on reflection time, or when the user demands daily introspection beyond their realistic capacity. Must avoid: in-depth emotional processing, coaching on mindset or motivation, designing general productivity systems, or restructuring the entire weekly calendar beyond the minimal reflection slots and their rules.
